title: South Africa: Cosatu Welcomes Parliament's Public Hearings On Climate Change
text:
Malawi: Conversation with President Mutharika press release 
Workers are the first to suffer the devastating effects of climate change, natural disasters, water scarcity, power outages, deforestation, desertification etc. 
Many of these are as a consequence of the profit at all costs approach by business with no concern for the costs to workers and communities. 
COSATU believes that it is possible and important to protect and ensure the sustainability of the environment as well as to ensure that the objectives of decent work and full employment are achieved as a matter of urgency. 
We do not believe that these two key objectives are opposed or cannot be met simultaneously. 
COSATU believes that it is critical for government, business, labour and community to work together to plan a sustainable future which protects the environment and ensures all workers have decent permanent jobs. 
The rapidly evolving renewable technologies are providing a unique opportunity for South Africa to create jobs and save the environment. 
Now is the time to do so. 
COSATU believes that renewable energy provides a win-win opportunity to address our energy needs in a sustainable cost effective safe manner. We remain deeply concerned about the role of nuclear energy. 
COSATU believes that nuclear energy is costly, environmentally dangerous, unsafe in terms of health risks etc. 
We strongly welcome the African National Congress's National General Council [NGC] policy document's inclusive call for South Africa's nuclear processes to be transparent. 
We further strongly applaud the commitment of the National Assembly's Committee on Energy's plan to hold public hearings on government's nuclear plans.” South Africa
